image.altText: Paula Wriedt stands in front of an oval holding a large concept plan

props.synopsis: When Paula Wriedt was elected to the Tasmanian parliament in 1996, a radio interviewer was more interested in her smile than her policies. Now a local government mayor, she is hopeful the situation for women in politics is improving.

title.children: It can be tough being a woman in politics, but former MP Paula Wriedt says she's enjoying being back in public life

image.altText: two men in dark coloured suits

props.synopsis: MP Nic Street, who has previously publicly disclosed his battle with mental health challenges, says the decision "has been coming for a while".

title.children: Mental health cited as Tasmania's minister for finance resigns from cabinet

image.altText: looking for modi podcast

props.synopsis:
Tasmania has more women in state parliament than men and we're the first Australian state to do so.

A new program encouraging even more women to enter the fray has just wrapped up with 11 graduates across the age and political spectrum getting a taste of what to expect. 

Bagging politicians is practically a national sport, but do female pollies cop it more than men?

It was a pretty rough ride for some of the trailblazers and although things have changed in recent years ... by how much?

Featuring Fiona Blackwood.

title.children: TASSIECAST: Have things changed for women in politics?

image.altText: A woman in pink pants crouching next to a preserved Tasmanian Tiger.

props.synopsis: The team behind a bid to 'de-extinct' the Tasmanian tiger says it has made significant breakthroughs, including producing a genome that is 99.9-per-cent accurate. Scientists say the scientific progress is welcome but they want to see the data.

title.children: Tasmanian tiger 'de-extinction' project claims genome breakthrough — but other scientists want to see the data

image.altText: Police cars and forensic officers in a suburban street

props.synopsis: A man accused of the attempted murder of his housemate in north-west Tasmania in 2022 has told a court he was convinced while listening to a podcast that he had to "kill the dark lord".

title.children: 'I thought I was Jesus Christ': Stabbing accused tells court of voices driving him to kill

image.altText: A graphic image of a curved three-storey building on a waterfront

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian hotel development locked in a Supreme Court dispute over whether the local council has the right to buy back the land it will be built on will bypass council planning laws to be assessed as a major infrastructure project.

title.children: Contentious hotel development at centre of legal debate green-lit by planning minister as major project

image.altText: Justice Gregory Geason looks off camera.

props.synopsis: Justice Gregory Geason has been on leave with pay for almost a year while he faced allegations of family violence, but the Tasmanian government appears to have no mechanism to suspend or remove him, even after his guilty verdict.

title.children: Did you miss? 📣 Judge guilty of causing concussion and bruising to a woman, but will remain on a $500,000 salary

image.altText: Five men dressed in formal suits stand on a red carpet

props.synopsis: Liam Payne's family say they're "heartbroken", and paid tribute to the former One Direction member's "kind, funny and brave soul" after he was found dead in Buenos Aires.

title.children: 'We love you Liam': One Direction members pay tribute to former bandmate Liam Payne

image.altText: A former student stares down the barrel of the camera with a serious expression. She is sitting on an orange couch.

props.synopsis: Young people allege verbal and physical assault at Tasmanian schools as bullying inquiry gets underway.

title.children: 'Broad daylight hate crime': Allegations of assault on LGBTQIA+ students in Tasmanian schools

image.altText: Two women crying while hugging a baby boy.

props.synopsis: An infant was allegedly sold by his father to a married couple desperate to have children in one of the latest cases of baby trafficking in Indonesia.

title.children: 'I want my husband to be punished': Indonesian police say a dad sold his 11-month-old baby to fund gambling

image.altText: Three men in suits smiling.

props.synopsis: Research prepared for the United States Congress argues Australia could abandon its $368 billion AUKUS push to buy nuclear-powered submarines.

title.children: Congressional report suggests Australia could dump plans to acquire AUKUS nuclear submarines

image.altText: A man with short grey hair smiles looking at the camera against a white background

props.synopsis: Craig Laidley has not been seen since he was swept out to sea after saving a struggling swimmer at a Bali beach.

title.children: Fears for Australian man missing in Bali after rescuing tourist in 'extreme' conditions

image.altText: a photo taken from a plane window shows a thin river with lots of twists and turns, and native vegetation on the bank.

props.synopsis: A long stretch of the Murray River and the massive Macquarie Marshes wetland in NSW could soon be designated "threatened ecological communities" by the federal government. Here's what that means.

title.children: Part of an iconic Australian river could soon be on the 'critically endangered' list

image.altText: South Africa's Anneke Bosch and Chloé Tryon celebrate in the middle of the pitch, preparing to hug

props.synopsis: Australia's domination of women's cricket ends sensationally in Dubai, with an inspired South Africa hammering them by eight wickets in the semifinal of the T20 World Cup.

title.children: Australia's reign ends as South Africa dominate in historic semifinal upset

image.altText: A man in a safari suit and a woman in a white dress walk on a red rock

props.synopsis: Charles and Diana's tour of Australia helped win back the hearts and minds of the monarch's subjects, but it was also where their relationship was forever altered.

title.children: King Charles and Queen Camilla are visiting Australia. In 1983, his tour with Diana was 'utterly traumatic'

image.altText: a man sitting at a computer

props.synopsis: For years, ATO investigators have been trawling the social media accounts of possible tax cheats looking for evidence of hidden lavish lifestyles. Now they're looking to automate the process.

title.children: Australian Taxation Office hopes to scrape social media, dark web with new tool against tax cheats

image.altText: A room with ocean views.

props.synopsis: From flipping the bird at a journalist to scooping up a clifftop abode before an election, "leaders who made decisions that felt good in the moment but have brought with them distracting headaches" has been a theme in politics this week.

title.children: Privately, there's one question surrounding Albanese's new Copacabana house that his colleagues are asking

image.altText: Wheat pours out of a collapsed silo.

props.synopsis: Emergency crews have been called to the collapse of two major wheat silos at Manildra's factory at Bomaderry on the New South Wales South Coast.

title.children: 'Major operation' underway after pair of silos collapse, spilling 2,500 tonnes of wheat near NSW river

image.altText: A photo of Todd Mengaldo in a hoodie kneeling down.

props.synopsis: Detectives investigating the death of Andrew Truman in Melbourne's CBD last week have confirmed he and the man wanted over the fatal assault were known to each other. Police are still searching for Todd Menegaldo in relation to the assault.

title.children: Police confirm link between Melbourne CBD assault victim and wanted man

image.altText: Sukhdeep and her daughter Ravneet Kaur. Ravneet stands behind Sukhdeep and embraces her.

props.synopsis: Sukhdeep Kaur moved to Australia on a temporary work visa. But things quickly unravelled when her employer was barred from sponsoring migrant workers.

title.children: Migrant employee facing deportation after employer breached sponsorship obligations

image.altText: A close up of a hand holding a electoral brochure

props.synopsis: As the state heads to the polls for the 2024 Queensland election, around 30 per cent of booths won't be fully accessible.

title.children: One third of Queensland voting booths are not fully accessible, forcing many to request postal ballots

image.altText: A doctor measures a patient's waist in her office.

props.synopsis: Despite widespread criticism, BMI continues to be the go-to for measuring some health risks. Now the "body roundness index" is gaining traction as a viable alternative. What's stopping it being used?

title.children: Why measuring body 'roundness' could be a better indicator of health than BMI

image.altText: Office-worker watches share prices at the ASX in Sydney

props.synopsis: Local stocks trade down, despite a mostly positive lead from the US market. China is releasing growth figures today but it's expected to be too early to see the impact of recent stimulus. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX falling on Friday as investors eye China economic update

image.altText: A close-up photograph of several black balls washed up on sand with lapping water in the background.

props.synopsis: It's time to test how much attention you've been paying to the news!

title.children: Weekly news quiz: Politicians with property portfolios, a bold starship test and mysterious balls surface on Sydney beaches

image.altText: A colourful close up photo of a brine shrimp

props.synopsis: Extreme close-ups of a mouse brain, octopus eggs and slime mould are among this year's Small World entries from 80 countries. Here are the judges' favourites.

title.children: Our tiny world in photos: The top 15 images from the 2024 photomicroscopy competition

image.altText: A man and two women in formal attire smile for the camera.

props.synopsis: The passing of the Equality Bill allows transgender people to change their birth certificates without having to underdo surgery, and falls in line with other state and territories.

title.children: 'A big step forward': Bill expanding transgender rights passes NSW parliament

image.altText: Peter Dutton, wearing a suit and tie, glares from his seat in parliament.

props.synopsis: The Coalition is well-placed for next year's election, but the looming battle over industrial relations could be more dangerous for Peter Dutton than his risky gamble to promote nuclear energy.

title.children: Whatever his policy, Peter Dutton will be a big target on workplace relations

image.altText: Andrew Barr press conference

props.synopsis: Just over half of the 213 policies that have been submitted for costing by the three biggest parties have been costed so far.

title.children: Here's what the ACT's major parties plan to spend if they're elected tomorrow

image.altText: An old black and white photo of Julia Garciacelay. She is looking at the camera with a slight smile.

props.synopsis: Not long before the horrific 1977 Easey Street murders, 19-year-old Julie Garciacelay vanished without a trace from her North Melbourne flat. As police make breakthroughs in the Easey Street case, a final push is underway to solve Julie's.

title.children: Julie Garciacelay vanished from her flat 49 years ago. Her mum is still hoping for answers

image.altText: Southern right whales mating

props.synopsis: A mating frenzy captured on camera off Western Australia's south coast is a promising sign for southern right numbers still recovering from decades of whaling, according to a marine biologist.

title.children: Whale mating 'orgy' off Australian coast a promising sign for southern right species

image.altText: Two vessels moored in mangroves.

props.synopsis: Rangers and traditional owners are calling for more federal surveillance and enforcement in remote waters after finding four Indonesian vessels fishing illegally in nearby creeks last week.

title.children: Indigenous rangers raise alarm after increase in foreign fishing vessels off Arnhem Land

image.altText: A picture of two women superimposed together

props.synopsis: The pair arrangement between two Liberal MPs with differing views was considered crucial, given the vote on a late-term abortion bill was expected to be tight.

title.children: How a pear-shaped pair exposed fractures within the SA Liberal Party

image.altText: White space suit with grey parts and red stripes

props.synopsis: The first woman on the moon will be wearing a Prada space suit, as part of NASA's first human mission to the lunar South Pole. The suit has been designed for NASA's Artemis III, planned for 2026.

title.children: Astronauts set to wear designer space suits in the first moon landing since 1972
